title: 107_s550
content: The Act titled "Indian and Alaska Native Foster Care and Adoption Services Amendments of 2001" allows Indian tribes to receive federal funds for foster care and adoption assistance. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act. This includes Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that have cooperative agreements with a State or submit arrangements for the provision of child welfare services. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act, including programs operated by Indian Tribal Organizations. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act, including programs operated by Indian Tribal Organizations. SEC. 479B outlines the programs operated by Indian Tribal Organizations. The part applies to Indian tribes operating programs under the same rules as states. Indian tribes can modify plan requirements for approval, specifying service areas and approving foster homes based on tribal standards for child safety. The federal medical assistance percentage for an Indian tribe is based on per capita income and relevant information submitted to the Secretary. The Secretary considers relevant information for calculating the per capita income of Indian tribes. Administrative expenditures are determined by the Secretary, ensuring tribes receive a proportion not less than that of a State. Tribes can use Federal or State funds to match payments under section 474. Other requirements can be modified upon request. Upon request, the Secretary may modify requirements under this part for Indian tribes to benefit children's safety. Intertribal consortiums can submit a single plan under section 471. Cooperative agreements between tribes or consortiums and states can be made for fund administration. Cooperative agreements between Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums and states incorporating specified provisions are valid and enforceable. Existing agreements remain in effect, with the option to modify or revoke. The Secretary must establish regulations within a year, consulting with tribes and tribal organizations. Definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' align with the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act is amended by this section, with the changes taking effect immediately upon enactment of the Act.
